prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spatially resolve the extended atmosphere in the continuum in Band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this SG we will resolve the extended atmosphere of Antares while measuring its flux density at 97.5 GHz. We will also search for asymmetries in the stellar disk. Most of this analysis will be carried out on the calibrated complex visibilities.
Accurate flux calibration is crucial for this experiment. One of the many Solar System flux calibrators will be sufficient to achieve the nominal 5-10% uncertainty at low frequencies in Band 3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Antares' circumstellar environment is very molecular poor (de Beck 2010) so we do not expect to detect any molecules, especially with such a small restoring beam and time on source. The correlator setup is thus simple and we therefore use the continuum mode with maximum bandwidth to achieve the best S/N.

From VLA spatially resolved observations of Antares' (Harper & Brown 2004), we estimate that the angular extent of Antares' extended atmosphere will be about 75mas at 100 GHz. Due to the nature of free-free opacity, its atmosphere is expected to be slightly smaller at progressively higher frequencies (i.e., higher frequencies probe deeper layers of the atmosphere).
To a good approximation, Antares will be a uniform disk at these continuum frequencies. We have simulated a few minutes on source in the most extended configuration during Cycle 3 (C36-8) and found that we will fully resolve the disk (i.e., we obtain visibilities at the first null). This is crucial to obtain robust size estimates for the extended atmosphere, and no other configurations during cycle 3 will be sufficient to do this. Our simulation (see science case attached) also shows that because of our excellent S/N, we will also be able to detect any possible hotspots or asymmetries if present in the atmosphere in Band 3.
The continuum emission will be very compact so the largest angular scale will be the size of the extended atmosphere.

Harper et al. (2009) list two Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) flux density measurements for Antares at 100 GHz (70 mJy) and at 250 GHz (345 mJy). This gives a spectral index of 1.74 for the extended atmosphere. This spectral index predicts a flux density of 67 mJy at 97.5 GHz.
Antares is a one of the brightest stars at mm and sub-mm continuum wavelengths, and the excellent sensitivity of ALMA means that a 1000sigma detection can be made in about 2.5 minutes in all Bands. Including overheads, this equates to 25 minutes per Band. Considering we can double the time on source by only increasing the total observing time per band to 30 minutes we have decided that 5 minutes on source per band is optimal. We thus should obtain dynamic range limited detections per band.

Antares is a one of the brightest stars at mm and sub-mm continuum wavelengths, and the excellent sensitivity of ALMA means that a 1000sigma detection can be made in about 2.5 minutes in all Bands. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spatially resolve the extended atmosphere in the continuum in Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this SG we will resolve the extended atmosphere of Antares while measuring its flux density at 233 GHz. We will also search for asymmetries in the stellar disk. Most of this analysis will be carried out on the calibrated complex visibilities.
Accurate flux calibration is crucial for this experiment. One of the many Solar System flux calibrators will be sufficient to achieve the nominal 5-10% uncertainty at low frequencies in Band 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Antares' circumstellar environment is very molecular poor (de Beck 2010) so we do not expect to detect any molecules, especially with such a small restoring beam and time on source. From VLA spatially resolved observations of Antares' (Harper & Brown 2004), we estimate that the angular extent of Antares' extended atmosphere will be about 70mas at 233 GHz.
To a good approximation, Antares will be a uniform disk at these continuum frequencies. For band 6 we have simulated a few minutes on source in the two most extended configurations during Cycle 3 (C36-7 and C36-8) and found that we will fully resolve the disk (i.e., we obtain visibilities at the first null). This is crucial to obtain robust size estimates for the extended atmosphere, and no other configurations during cycle 3 will be sufficient to do this. Our simulation (see science case attached) also shows that because of our excellent S/N, we will also be able to detect any possible hotspots or asymmetries if present in the atmosphere in Band 6.
The continuum emission will be very compact so the largest angular scale will be the size of the extended atmosphere.

Harper et al. (2009) list two Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) flux density measurements for Antares at 100 GHz (70 mJy) and at 250 GHz (345 mJy). This gives a spectral index of 1.74 for the extended atmosphere. This spectral index predicts a flux density of 305 mJy at 233 GHz.
Antares is a one of the brightest stars at mm and sub-mm continuum wavelengths, and the excellent sensitivity of ALMA means that a 1000sigma detection can be made in about 2.5 minutes in all Bands. Including overheads, this equates to 25 minutes per Band. Considering we can double the time on source by only increasing the total observing time per band to 30 minutes we have decided that 5 minutes on source per band is optimal. We thus should obtain dynamic range limited detections per band.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Spatially resolve the extended atmosphere in the continuum in Band 9
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
In this SG we will resolve the extended atmosphere of Antares while measuring its flux density at 680 GHz. We will also search for asymmetries in the stellar disk. Most of this analysis will be carried out on the calibrated complex visibilities.
Accurate flux calibration is crucial for this experiment. One of the many Solar System flux calibrators will be sufficient to achieve the nominal 10-15% uncertainty at high frequencies in Band 9.
Antares is an excellent science target to test the capabilities of these very high ALMA frequencies on, as it is extremely bright (i.e., 2-3 Jy) and should show few if any asymetries.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Antares' circumstellar environment is very molecular poor (de Beck 2010) so we do not expect to detect any molecules, especially with such a small restoring beam and time on source. The correlator setup is thus simple and we therefore use the continuum mode with maximum bandwidth to achieve the best S/N.

From VLA spatially resolved observations of Antares' (Harper & Brown 2004), we estimate that the angular extent of Antares' extended atmosphere will be about 65mas at 680 GHz.
To a good approximation, Antares will be a uniform disk at these continuum frequencies. For band 9 we have simulated a few minutes on source in the most extended configuration during Cycle 3 (C36-8) and found that we will fully resolve the disk (i.e., we obtain visibilities at the first null). This is crucial to obtain robust size estimates for the extended atmosphere, and no other configurations during cycle 3 will be sufficient to do this. Our simulation (see science case attached) also shows that because of our excellent S/N, we will also be able to detect any possible hotspots or asymmetries if present in the atmosphere in Band 9.
The continuum emission will be very compact so the largest angular scale will be the size of the extended atmosphere.

Harper et al. (2009) list two Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) flux density measurements for Antares at 100 GHz (70 mJy) and at 250 GHz (345 mJy). This gives a spectral index of 1.74 for the extended atmosphere. This spectral index predicts a flux density of 1970 mJy at 680 GHz.
Antares is a one of the brightest stars at mm and sub-mm continuum wavelengths, and the excellent sensitivity of ALMA means that a 1000sigma detection can be made in about 2.5 minutes in all Bands. Including overheads, this equates to 25 minutes per Band. Considering we can double the time on source by only increasing the total observing time per band to 30 minutes we have decided that 5 minutes on source per band is optimal. We thus should obtain dynamic range limited detections per band.

The correlator setup is thus simple and we therefore use the continuum mode with maximum bandwidth to achieve the best S/N.

From VLA spatially resolved observations of Antares' (Harper & Brown 2004), we estimate that the angular extent of Antares' extended atmosphere will be about 60 mas at 870 GHz.

Harper et al. (2009) list two Owens Valley Radio Observatory (OVRO) flux density measurements for Antares at 100 GHz (70 mJy) and at 250 GHz (345 mJy). This gives a spectral index of 1.74 for the extended atmosphere. This spectral index predicts a flux density of 3025 mJy at 870 GHz.
Antares is a one of the brightest stars at mm and sub-mm continuum wavelengths, and the excellent sensitivity of ALMA means that a 1000sigma detection can be made in about 2.5 minutes in all Bands. Including overheads, this equates to 25 minutes per Band. We thus should obtain dynamic range limited detections per band.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The nearby red supergiant and SN II progenitor Antares (alpha Sco A) is an ideal target for studying the mechanisms that both extend the atmospheres of M supergiants and drive the poorly understood mass outflows. The stellar parameters and age of Antares (~13 Myr) are well determined, and the companion alpha Sco B provides an in-situ probe of the RSG's mass-loss rate, making this system an ideal test of theoretical models.
With the Cycle 3 long baselines and available frequencies ALMA is now able to probe the crucial layers above the photosphere where much of the energy is injected into the stellar outflow. We propose to use ALMA at its maximum spatial resolution to perform thermal continuum tomography which will probe through the layers of the chromosphere and Molsphere for the first time, permitting the temperature structure to be mapped and the energy balance determined. These constraints will be used to test theoretial mass loss models, and the proposed observations will also permit a test of the physical parameters of its Molsphere.
